quality_assessment.completeness: Complete global terrestrial coverage. Some small islands and arid regions may have limited hydrological model accuracy.
quality_assessment.reliability_rating: high - WRI Aqueduct is the most widely used global water risk assessment tool, cited in thousands of peer-reviewed papers and used by major corporations, governments, and conservation organizations.

documentation.citation: Hofste, R., Reig, P., & Schleifer, L. (2019). 17 Countries, Home to One-Quarter of the World's Population, Face Extremely High Water Stress. World Resources Institute. Available at: https://www.wri.org/aqueduct
conservation_applications: Identifying water-stressed ANPs requiring priority attention
Assessing vulnerability of aquatic and riparian ecosystems
Planning climate adaptation strategies for water-dependent species
Evaluating upstream land use impacts on downstream protected areas
Supporting water security planning for communities in and around ANPs

anp_spatial_relationship.description: Sub-basin polygons (HydroBASINS level 6) intersecting ANP. Area-weighted average computed.
important_caveats: Many pristine ANPs show 'No Data' because there are no water withdrawals to measure
Water stress measures human demand vs. supply - not natural water availability
Sub-basin boundaries don't align with ANP boundaries - values reflect broader watershed
High values in arid regions reflect regional water scarcity, not ANP-specific issues

sources.name: NASA GEDI L4A Aboveground Biomass Density

coverage.notes: Lidar-based forest biomass from ISS orbit (51.6° latitude coverage)

anp_spatial_relationship.description: GEDI provides 25m diameter footprint samples, not continuous coverage. Statistics computed from all available footprints within ANP.
anp_spatial_relationship.aggregation_method: mean/max/std of AGBD values from sampled footprints
important_caveats: GEDI samples are sparse - not every location within ANP is measured
Coverage gaps exist due to clouds, orbit gaps, and data quality filters
Small ANPs may have few or no GEDI footprints
Temporal coverage: April 2019 - present, but data availability varies

documentation.summary: NASA's Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) provides space-based lidar measurements of forest structure, including aboveground biomass density (AGBD). GEDI L4A data represents the most accurate global estimate of forest biomass available.
documentation.description: GEDI is a full-waveform lidar instrument mounted on the International Space Station (ISS), providing high-resolution 3D structure measurements of Earth's forests. The L4A product converts these lidar waveforms into estimates of Aboveground Biomass Density (AGBD) in Megagrams (tonnes) per hectare. This enables direct quantification of forest carbon stocks for climate monitoring and conservation planning.

methodology.data_collection: Spaceborne lidar aboard ISS. Three lasers produce 8 parallel ground tracks with 25m diameter footprints spaced 60m apart along-track.
methodology.processing: Full-waveform lidar returns processed to extract relative height metrics (RH25-RH100), which are input to AGBD prediction models calibrated against field measurements.
methodology.validation: L4A models trained on 3.1 million in-situ biomass measurements from 29 countries, validated against independent field plots.

limitations: Sample-based: not every location is measured, coverage depends on orbit and data quality
ISS orbit limits coverage to ±51.6° latitude
Clouds and data quality filters create gaps in coverage
AGBD model uncertainty increases in very dense forests (>300 Mg/ha) and arid woodlands

quality_assessment.accuracy: RMSE ~30-40 Mg/ha for AGBD predictions. Higher accuracy in temperate forests, lower in tropical dense forests.
quality_assessment.completeness: Varies by ANP size and location. Large tropical ANPs typically have good coverage; small or high-latitude ANPs may have gaps.
quality_assessment.reliability_rating: high - GEDI is the most advanced spaceborne lidar mission for forest biomass, with rigorous calibration and validation.

documentation.citation: Dubayah, R., et al. (2022). GEDI L4A Footprint Level Aboveground Biomass Density, Version 2.1. NASA EOSDIS Land Processes DAAC.
conservation_applications: Quantifying forest carbon stocks in ANPs for REDD+ and climate reporting
Monitoring forest degradation through biomass change detection
Prioritizing ANPs for forest restoration based on current biomass levels
Valuing ecosystem services (carbon sequestration) for conservation finance

sources.name: CONEVAL Social Lag Index (Indice de Rezago Social)
sources.provider: CONEVAL (Consejo Nacional de Evaluación de la Política de Desarrollo Social)

coverage.notes: Municipal-level data. ANPs matched via localities within bounding box.

anp_spatial_relationship.description: Municipalities identified by finding INEGI ITER localities within ANP bounds, then matched to CONEVAL municipal data.
anp_spatial_relationship.aggregation_method: Population-weighted mean of IRS across intersecting municipalities
important_caveats: Uses bounding box, not exact polygon - may include nearby municipalities
Marine and island ANPs typically have no intersecting municipalities
Large ANPs may span high and low social lag municipalities - average can be misleading
Data represents surrounding communities, not necessarily people inside ANP boundary

documentation.summary: CONEVAL's Social Lag Index (Índice de Rezago Social) is a composite indicator measuring social development deficits at the municipal level, including education, health access, and housing conditions. This data helps assess the socioeconomic context of communities in and around ANPs.
documentation.description: The IRS is constructed from Census 2020 microdata using Principal Component Analysis on 11 indicators covering illiteracy, school attendance, basic education, health services access, and housing conditions (floor, sanitation, water, drainage, electricity, appliances). The index ranges from approximately -2.5 (very low lag = best conditions) to +4.0 (very high lag = worst conditions), with five categories: Muy bajo, Bajo, Medio, Alto, Muy alto.

methodology.data_collection: INEGI Census 2020 microdata at locality and household level, aggregated to municipal level.
methodology.processing: 11 indicators extracted and standardized. Principal Component Analysis produces single index value. Categories assigned based on national distribution quartiles.
methodology.validation: Cross-validated against poverty measurements (CONEVAL multidimensional poverty). Consistent methodology since 2000 enables temporal comparison.

limitations: Municipal level may mask intra-municipal variation
ANP boundaries don't align with municipal boundaries
Index measures lag (deficits), not poverty directly
Some remote areas may have data quality issues in underlying census

quality_assessment.accuracy: High - based on census enumeration with national coverage
quality_assessment.completeness: Complete coverage of all 2,469 municipalities
quality_assessment.reliability_rating: high - CONEVAL is Mexico's official poverty measurement agency, IRS methodology is well-documented and peer-reviewed

documentation.citation: CONEVAL (2021). Índice de Rezago Social 2020 a nivel municipal y por localidad. Ciudad de México: CONEVAL.
conservation_applications: Understanding socioeconomic context of communities dependent on ANP resources
Identifying ANPs where conservation may conflict with or support development
Prioritizing community-based conservation programs
Assessing equity implications of protected area policies
Planning sustainable livelihood interventions

coverage.notes: Extracted for coastal ANPs. Class 95 = Mangroves, Class 90 = Herbaceous wetland.

anp_spatial_relationship.description: 10m resolution land cover classification. Mangrove pixels summed within ANP boundary.
anp_spatial_relationship.aggregation_method: sum of pixel areas where class == 95 (mangrove) or 90 (wetland)
important_caveats: Single year (2021) snapshot - no time series
May underestimate mangroves in mixed/degraded areas
Herbaceous wetland (class 90) includes marshes, not just mangrove-adjacent areas

documentation.summary: Mangrove extent extracted from ESA WorldCover 2021 land cover classification (class 95). Provides 10m resolution mangrove mapping for coastal ANPs.
documentation.description: ESA WorldCover is a global land cover product at 10m resolution based on Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 imagery. Class 95 specifically identifies mangrove forests, while class 90 captures herbaceous wetlands. This data enables monitoring of coastal ecosystem extent within ANPs.

methodology.data_collection: Sentinel-1 SAR and Sentinel-2 optical imagery from 2021.
methodology.processing: Machine learning classification trained on global reference data. Mangrove class validated against existing mangrove maps.
methodology.validation: Overall accuracy ~75% globally. Mangrove class has high producer/user accuracy in tropical coastal areas.

limitations: Single year - cannot detect trends
May confuse mangroves with other coastal vegetation in some areas
10m resolution may miss narrow mangrove fringes

quality_assessment.accuracy: High for mangrove detection in major mangrove regions (Mexico's Pacific and Caribbean coasts)
quality_assessment.completeness: Complete coverage for all coastal ANPs
quality_assessment.reliability_rating: high - ESA's official global land cover product with extensive validation

documentation.citation: Zanaga, D., et al. (2022). ESA WorldCover 10m 2021 v200. Zenodo. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.7254221
related_sources: Global Mangrove Watch (GMW) - historical time series
ESA WorldCover land_cover dataset (already in ANP data)
conservation_applications: Baseline mapping of mangrove extent in coastal ANPs
Identifying ANPs with significant mangrove ecosystems
Supporting blue carbon accounting initiatives
Prioritizing coastal protection and restoration

coverage.notes: Coverage varies by accessibility and naturalist activity. Urban and accessible areas have more data.

anp_spatial_relationship.description: Georeferenced observations within ANP bounding box. Research-grade only (community-verified IDs).
anp_spatial_relationship.aggregation_method: count of unique species and total observations
important_caveats: Bounding box query may include observations outside exact ANP boundary
Heavily biased toward accessible areas and charismatic species
Observation density reflects naturalist activity, not true biodiversity
Complements GBIF data - some overlap but also unique records

documentation.summary: Citizen science biodiversity observations from iNaturalist (known as Naturalista in Mexico). Provides species occurrence data contributed by naturalists and verified by community consensus.
documentation.description: iNaturalist is a citizen science platform where users submit photographs of organisms with GPS coordinates. The community identifies species, and observations achieving consensus are marked 'research-grade'. Data complements professional surveys with broader spatial and temporal coverage, though with inherent sampling biases.

methodology.data_collection: Photographs submitted via mobile app or web with automatic GPS tagging.
methodology.processing: Community identification with AI suggestions. Research-grade requires: photo, date, coordinates, and 2/3 community agreement on ID.
methodology.validation: Community consensus model. Experts can override. Data exported to GBIF weekly.

spatial_temporal.spatial_coverage: Global, but concentrated in populated and accessible areas

limitations: Strong sampling bias toward roads, trails, and populated areas
Underrepresents nocturnal, cryptic, and inaccessible species
Species richness correlates with human activity, not true biodiversity
ID accuracy varies - rare/difficult species may be misidentified

quality_assessment.accuracy: Research-grade observations have high ID accuracy for common species. Rare species IDs should be verified.
quality_assessment.completeness: Incomplete - represents accessible areas. Remote ANPs have sparse data.
quality_assessment.reliability_rating: medium - Valuable for common species and accessible areas, but should not be sole biodiversity assessment

documentation.citation: iNaturalist contributors (2024). iNaturalist Research-grade Observations. iNaturalist.org. Accessed via API.
conservation_applications: Rapid biodiversity assessment for understudied ANPs
Detecting range expansions and invasive species
Engaging local communities in conservation monitoring
Supplementing professional species inventories

coverage_rules.terrestrial: Only land-based ANPs (excludes purely marine areas)
coverage_rules.simec_registered: Only ANPs with SIMEC species inventories (~61 ANPs)

category_descriptions.administrative: Protected area boundaries and legal designations
category_descriptions.biodiversity: Species occurrences, taxonomic data, conservation status
